results.title: The FBI
results.creator_credit: George McCowan, Charles Larson, Quinn Martin, Seven Arts and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This television series screened between 1965 and 1975. Its production was endorsed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with episodes based on actual FBI case files. Its emotionless portrayal of agents tracking down criminals provides a cool and compelling atmosphere. This episode called “Southwind” sees a banker escaping on a plane with two million dollars. Not only has he stolen money he has left gambling debts and a man injured in hospital. With no leads it is left to the methodical actions of the FBI agents to find the missing banker. This is a series where politics and drama meet as each episode was allegedly approved by J. Edgar Hoover himself. Cast includes Efrem Zimblist Jr., Philip Abbot and William Reynolds.

results.title: The Antipodeans
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. Arthur Boyd and John Perceval had progressed through the ‘angry decade’ and younger painters joined them: Robert Dickerson, Charles Blackman, John Brack, Clifton Pugh and David Boyd, and two greats who were to influence the future, Sidney Nolan and Leonard French.

results.title: The Fatal game
results.creator_credit: Richard Dennison, James Heyward, J A A Films and Orana Films
results.brief_description: Australian Mike Rheinberger has made six attempts to reach the top of Mount Everest. His dream of conquering the mountain has become an obsession. On his seventh attempt, he and companion Mark Whetu finally reach the top and soon plunge into nightmare. After the elation of victory comes the realisation that it is too late to walk down to camp before nightfall. At 29,000 feet, they bivouac on a ridge, enduring temperatures of minus 25 degrees Celsius. The pair survives the night in what in called “the death zone” only to be awakened to a situation of extreme urgency. Mark Whetu is left to make a decision that will stay with him forever …

results.title: The Family that dwelt apart
results.creator_credit: Yvon Mallette, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Cartoon animation of a story by E.B. White, first published in the New Yorker magazine in 1937. This is a tall Yankee tale about a family of seven fisherfolk who are living quite happily as the sole inhabitants of a small island in Barnetuck Bay until word somehow gets to the mainland that they are in distress. What happens when rescue attempts are launched makes an amusing story, illustrated with wit and verve by the film animation. Narrated by E.B. White. Also available on DVD [319319].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yvon Mallette, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Fat film
results.creator_credit: Frank J. Lisciandro, John Lengsfelder, Katherine Lisciandro, Image Associates and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: Americans have the most fat-filled diet in the world. On an average, over 40% of the calories eaten daily by Americans are fats. A diet high in fat dramatically increases the risk of coronary heart disease, stroke, atherosclerosis, diabetes and cancer. This program outlines constructive nutritional advice for reducing fat content in our diets and thereby improving our health and decreasing our cholesterol level.

results.title: The Camera image: more than a record
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program examines the pre-history of photography, discussing the concepts of visual perspective, mechanical devices leading to the invention of the camera, and the cultural needs that generated the invention of photography. The special qualities of the camera and its artistic capabilities are discussed.

results.title: Expressing a twentieth century vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program probes how the photograph has been used as a metaphor to describe the photographer’s inner state. This is in contrast to traditional approaches to realistic photography. Individual photographers discuss the use of metaphor in their own experiences and works.

results.title: The Family album
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing image”.
Highlights the most frequent subject of photographers past and present, the family portrait. Provides a history of family portraiture, including daguerreotypes and wet-plate photography, as well as the development of Kodak roll-film cameras. Includes interviews with leading contemporary photographers who specialise in family portraiture.

results.title: Solutions to images
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program contains a technical survey of the main photographic processes from the daguerreotype to the Kodak#1. Explores an antique tintype gallery and shows a wet-collodion negative made during the American Civil War.
